title: The ugly F1 feature making a comeback
text:
F1: Force India reveals its 2017 car, the Mercedes-powered VJM10 February 23, 2017 10:06am by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS THE new Force India Formula 1 car has shirked one of its uglier features in recent seasons — only to reintroduce another that had been consigned to history. 
Sergio Perez and new teammate Esteban Ocon pulled the wraps off the Mercedes-powered VJM10 at Silverstone, the circuit located opposite Force India’s factory. 
A key feature of recent Force Indias has been its unusual nose treatment. 
Some called them ‘nostrils’; others suggested they looked like something you’d more likely find in a surf lifesaver’s hut. The snout of last year’s Force India. Source: AFP 
But engineers have consigned them to history on the VJM10. The new car’s nose continues a similar sort of philosophy but in a slightly more aesthetically pleasing way. 
A reconfigured livery sees silver rather than black now the car’s predominant colour, the colours making the protrusions look almost like fangs either side of the central extension. Force India’s 2017 nose. Source: AFP 
But as the good engineer giveth with one hand, they taketh away with the other. Cast your eye further up the nose towards the cockpit. 
The VJM10 has brought back the stepped nose. It’s hard to miss the step in the VJM10’s nose. Source: Supplied 
The ‘stepped nose’ arrived on the F1 grid in 2012 after safety concerns prompted a rewrite of the technical rules. 
Chassis cockpits were being designed higher and higher to direct air under the floor of the car to generate downforce, causing the tip of cars’ noses to rise to the point that 
So, for 2012, the FIA mandated that the nose cone could only be a certain height — except that was different to the maximum height of the chassis monocoque. 
That led to many teams adopting the stepped nose in order to both satisfy the rules and enjoy the benefits of underfloor airflow. 
The FIA tried to quell fans ire by allowing teams to fit a vanity panel over the step in 2013, before the step was properly eradicated amid the hybrid-power rule changes of 2014. 
While neither Sauber nor Renault have designed a stepped nose into their cars, it remains to be seen if any other 2017 contenders will interpret the new rules in the same way as Force India. Perez and Ocon reveal the new car at the team’s launch. Source: Supplied 
PEREZ: I EXPECT A VERY BIG YEAR FOR THE TEAM The new season is the team’s 10th under the ownership of Vijay Mallya with 2016’s fourth-placed Constructors’ Championship finish the best in Force India’s history. 
Considered to be the best ‘pound-for-pound’ outfit in F1, Force India are aiming to continue their progress in the first year of the sport’s new aero design rules with boss Mallya targeting a top-three finish. 
“We are dreaming big but we’re going to give it all we’ve got,” Mallya vowed. “All the data shows this is a cracker of a car.” The Force India VJM10 Mercedes. Source: Supplied 
Perez claimed podium finishes in Monaco and Azerbaijan in 2016, believing there are plenty of reasons to be very hopeful Force India can take the next step this year. 
“I trust totally this team,” said Perez. “I expect a very big year for the team.” 
“In none of the teams that I’ve been with in Formula 1 I’ve seen this level of confidence, organisation, everyone doing their jobs. We have plenty of reasons to be hoping for a great year. I think Force India will give a big surprise this year, I have a feeling we have done a tremendous job over the winter.” The Force India VJM10 Mercedes. Source: Supplied 
In keeping with the other teams to have launched their 2017 car so far, Force India’s technical chief Andrew Green said the VJM10 contained few carry-over parts from last year’s car. 
Perez said simulation date pointed to lap-time gains of up to six seconds. 
“It’s a big step from last year to this year,” the Mexican added. “We expect four to six seconds how much quicker the car goes. 
“The amount of downforce we are going to be generating this year, I think I’ll have to go back and keep training my neck!” The Force India VJM10 Mercedes. Source: Supplied 
Having enjoyed almost year-on-year progress up the grid over the last decade, Force India finished ahead of former champions Williams and McLaren last season. 
Nico Hulkenberg’s winter departure for Renault means the team’s line-up undergoes its first change since 2014, with Mercedes protege Ocon joining Perez after making his F1 debut with Manor in the second half of last season. The Force India VJM10 Mercedes. Source: Supplied 
Sky F1 analyst Mark Hughes said: “Realistically, to get in the top three would require one of the big teams really messing up big time. We’ve got a big aerodynamic change in regulations coming for 2017 and you never know, it’s possible that somebody does mess up in those circumstances. 
“But in the long run, the top teams invariably end up in the top positions. If they could keep banging in fourth and fifth places in the Constructors’ Championship, because that brings it’s own reward and helps towards the team’s stability as well, they’d be doing really well.” 
- with Sky Sports
